Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E: Multiscale Integrations of Exoplanetary Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
With thousands of planets outside our solar system detected in recent years, there is an emerging need for tools that help extract scientific knowledge from the large amount of observational data. The purpose of this project is to develop a tool for understanding the long-time orbital evolution of interacting exoplanets. Innovative tools are needed because many exoplanet systems exhibit configurations distinct from that of our solar system, rendering existing approaches insufficient. The tools developed in this research project will facilitate the detection of exoplanets and the identification of their parameters, help explain how observed systems evolved to their current configuration, and help determine whether an observed system is habitable by common life forms. The research will contribute not only to mathematics and astronomy, but will also introduce the general public to scientific thinking and discovery. For instance, its implementation will be adapted to a free screen saver with social media interface, which will allow those outside academia to perform and enjoy exoplanet detection and evolution prediction.

Computational efficiency is a central concern in this project. Changes in planet orbits induced by nonlinear planet-planet interactions are oftentimes slow, requiring the simulation of a trajectory for billions of orbits. Moreover, many of the aforementioned scientific investigations require large numbers of trajectories, and hence direct simulations are too time- and storage-consuming. Fortunately, planetary systems contain a small parameter of planet/star mass ratio, which makes them nearly-integrable and exhibiting different dynamics over well-separated timescales. This research project utilizes this fact and achieves accelerated simulation. Several outstanding challenges are the lack of analytical expressions for averaging integrals, approximation errors due to small but not infinitesimal mass ratio, and the inaccuracy of averaging near passage through resonance. These challenges are addressed by two mathematical contributions. One is a multiscale method that allows the computation of long time orbital evolution by averaging over fast scale nonlinear oscillations. This method is based on numerical resolution of homological PDEs derived from near identity transformations. The other is an adaptive procedure that allows accurate integration through transient resonances, which is accomplished by matched asymptotic expansions with an appropriate near-resonance rescaling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thousands of planets outside the Solar system, termed as exoplanets, have been detected in recent years. The increasing amount of observational data call for tools that help extract scientific knowledge from these data. Research supported by this award develop some of these tools, including algorithms for the accurate and efficient simulations of these planetary systems. Such algorithms are in great demand. For instance, to infer the existence of exoplanets and identify their parameters, inverse problems often need to be solved, which require the accurate resolution of a large number of forward problems, each corresponding to one simulation. Developments in this project make such computationally intensive simulations feasible, by exploiting the fact that planetary dynamics have structures spanning multiple timescales. More specifically (and as an illustration), each planet follows an orbit, and its movement along this orbit (known as revolution) corresponds to a fast timescale of nonlinear oscillations. At the same time, the geometric shapes of orbits change at rates much slower than those of the revolutions, due to the interaction between the nonlinear oscillations, and these changes contain important scientific information. To achieve computation acceleration, this project quantifies how fast scale oscillations effectively contribute to the slow scale dynamics, and then simulates the effective dynamics using large timesteps without resolving the fast scale details. At the same time, this project strives to respect the mechanical nature of planetary systems by preserving their intrinsic structures, such as conserved energy and momentum, or more fundamentally, symplecticity (and Lie group structure, when available), so that higher accuracy of the simulation can be warranted. Mathematically, this combined objective is accomplished by formulating planetary problems as nearly integrable systems and fusing (and developing) tools in dynamical systems, computational math and geometric mechanics; the outcome methods are then applied to downstream astrophysical problems.

Although planetary dynamics have been studied by giants of the scientific world for centuries, traditional tools were mainly developed for the Solar system. Exoplanetary systems, on the other hand, can be significantly different due to, for instance, large eccentricity, high inclination, and/or more than one host star. These are the reason that developments of this project are helpful. Mathematical and computational outcomes included tools for simulating and analyzing multiscale / highly oscillatory / nearly integrable / mechanical systems, whose applicability is not restricted to planetary systems. Meanwhile, specific astrophysical problems were also investigated. For instance, circumbinary systems, which host planets revolving around two stars instead of one, have been lately detected and believed to be rather common, and this project analyzed their architectural properties using dynamics approaches: by showing the dynamical instability of a range of architectures, they were found to be less likely. Another example is the recent dynamics-based study of the habitability of Earth-like planet around binary stars. For this study, student, collaborator and the PI developed analytical and numerical tools that can accurately account for the spins of planet and their interactions with orbital evolutions. These tools were then employed to illustrate that, in common situations, Earth-like planets around binary stars have more stable spin-axis than those in single-star systems. The importance of this discovery is that stable spin-axis implies more stable climate, which strongly correlates with better habitability under otherwise similar conditions.

Significant scientific by-products of the main sponsored research were also obtained. For example, as understandings and quantifications of nonlinear oscillations continued to substantiate throughout this project, collaborators and the PI discovered that a dynamical phenomenon called parametric resonance can remedy a lack of controllability. It can be used as a mechanism to control the macroscopic behaviors of a large class of systems based on perturbations introduced at microscopic scales. This discovery initiated multiple engineering and physical applications as well as deeper theoretical investigations, which will be the subjects of later NSF sponsored projects. Another by-product is on the quantification of how small noisy perturbations can induce global effects to dynamical systems. While the case of gradient systems has been well understood in the literature, this project focused on mechanical systems which are non-gradient. One motivation comes from planetary dynamics, for which one can never model all the objects in the universe, and the effects of a large number of distant unmodeled celestial objects are approximated by noisy perturbations to the modeled (planetary) system. The purpose of the sponsored research is to answer whether these noises can drastically alter the evolutions of the interested planetary systems.

Besides mathematical research making contributions to astrophysics, broader impacts of this project also included various educational efforts, such as student/postdoc training, the promotion of underrepresented groups? participation, summer REU, course development, K12 outreach, and public science.
